content: The "Safety Net Enhancement Act" includes administrative reforms such as extended benefits trigger, adjustments in earnings credited to State accounts, and interest-free advances to States meeting funding goals. It also repeals the tax on unemployment compensation and establishes a Safety Net Review Commission. The Safety Net Enhancement Act includes administrative reforms like extended benefits trigger adjustments and changes in earnings credited to State accounts based on funding goals. The Safety Net Enhancement Act includes administrative reforms related to adjustments in earnings credited to State accounts based on funding goals. If a State account exceeds the funding goal, the amount credited will increase by an interest premium, and if it falls below the goal, the amount credited will decrease by an interest penalty. The Safety Net Enhancement Act introduces adjustments in earnings credited to State accounts based on funding goals. If a State account exceeds the goal, it will receive an interest premium, capped at $2,500,000 per quarter. The interest premium is calculated based on the excess balance in the account compared to the funding goal. The Secretary will adjust interest premiums if they exceed penalties in a quarter. The term 'interest penalty' is defined as one-half of one percent of the excess of the funding goal over the average daily balance in the State account. The Trust Fund allocation formula involves calculating one-half of one percent of the amount creditable to each State account under subsection (e). The funding goal of a State is determined by the average unemployment insurance benefits paid during a calendar quarter. The Trust Fund allocation formula calculates one-half of one percent of the amount creditable to each State account under subsection (e) of the Social Security Act. The funding goal of a State is determined by the average unemployment insurance benefits paid during a calendar quarter. The term 'percentage value' is defined for excess balances in State accounts in the Unemployment Trust Fund. The Social Security Act is amended to adjust interest rates on repayment of advances, and a report on funding sources for interest premiums is required within six months of the Act's enactment. The amendments made by this section regarding interest penalties funding premiums will be effective for calendar years starting after December 31, 2010. SEC. 103 amends the Social Security Act to restrict interest-free advances to states meeting funding goals in the Unemployment Trust Fund. The amendment applies to calendar years after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 104 relates to state collection of federal unemployment tax. SEC. 104 amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow states to collect federal unemployment tax. The Internal Revenue Code allows states to collect federal unemployment tax from employers who pay contributions into the state's unemployment fund. Employers must submit the tax to the state rather than to the Secretary, and timely payment to the state is considered timely paid for tax purposes. The federal tax imposed by this chapter must be paid by employers to the state, not the Secretary, by the deadline to be considered timely. States electing to collect this tax must transmit the amount to the Secretary along with employer tax returns. Additional information may be required by the Secretary through regulations. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for chapter 23 of the Internal Revenue Code. The Code is amended by replacing the item for section 3311 with new items. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2007. Required distribution of state-specific information packets. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 requires states to distribute information packets on unemployment insurance eligibility. This amendment applies to certifications of states for 2008 and beyond, with an exception for states not meeting in a regular session closing in 2008. Repeal of tax on unemployment compensation under Title II. The tax on unemployment compensation under Title II is repealed, with amendments to related sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The effective date for these changes is after December 31, 2007. The Safety Net Review Commission is established by the Secretary of Labor to evaluate various employment assistance programs and make recommendations for their improvement. The Safety Net Review Commission consists of 11 members appointed by the President, President pro tempore of the Senate, and Speaker of the House of Representatives. Members represent business, labor, State government, and the public. Qualifications include appointing representatives of business and labor. The Safety Net Review Commission consists of 11 members appointed by the President, President pro tempore of the Senate, and Speaker of the House of Representatives. Members represent business, labor, State government, and the public. Vacancies in the Commission are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, and the President appoints the Chairman from among its members. The Safety Net Review Commission may engage technical assistance as needed. The Secretary of Labor must provide staff, facilities, and data required by the Commission. SEC. 305. COMPENSATION. Members of the Commission receive compensation at the rate of pay for level V of the Executive Schedule for each day of duty and are allowed travel expenses. The Commission will submit a report with findings and recommendations to the President and Congress within 6 months of the Act's enactment. The Commission will terminate 2 months after submitting the report.
